<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">ARC5502</span> - Advanced studies in architecture 4<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ARC5502">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-architecture.html">Department of Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Eduardo Kairuz">Mr Eduardo Kairuz</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Eduardo Kairuz">Mr Eduardo Kairuz</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ARC5502&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ARC5502&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ARC5502&amp;tpCode=T1-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 1</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ARC5502&amp;tpCode=T2-58&amp;tpYear=2019">Trimester 2</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ARC5502&amp;tpCode=T4-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 4</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ARC5502">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Term 1 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Trimester 2 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus block of classes</a>)</li><li>Term 4 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus block of classes</a>)</li><li>Term 4 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-overseas.html">Overseas</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Trimester 2 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus block of classes</a>)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-prato.html">Prato</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Trimester 2 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus block of classes</a>)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Admission to Master of Architecture or by permission, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit explores aspects of architectural media. This unit examines a range of discursive and material aspects of architectural media. It will take into consideration various cultural, social, and technological factors utilizing historical, theoretical, and projective approaches. Investigations will incorporate various methodologies and diverse points of view with an underlying concern for the implications for architectural design. The unit will foster skills necessary for assessing and contributing to the built environment.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Have become acquainted with theories and practices shaping architecture;</li>
<li>Have a wider comprehension of architectural media;</li>
<li>Have gained enhanced skills in articulating architectural ideas;</li>
<li>Understand and be able to apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the unit of study.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 3 contact hours plus 9 hours of independent study, or equivalent.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">BMS5007</span> - Biotechnology: Commercialising biomedical science<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BMS5007">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biomedical-sciences.html">School of Biomedical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ramesh Rajan">Prof Ramesh Rajan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ian Cooke">Prof Ian Cooke</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMS5007&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMS5007&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BMS5007">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in a Postgraduate degree</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Please note: The teaching dates for this unit vary from the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">standard teaching dates</a><span class="hbk-print-url">standard teaching dates (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span> for this teaching period.</p>
<p>Unit discontinuation and penalty dates for these units are different to other units taught in the same teaching period.</p>
<p>Please refer to the information available on the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">Faculty non standard teaching dates page</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Faculty non standard teaching dates page (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates</a>)</span> to avoid <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">academic and financial penalties</a><span class="hbk-print-url">academic and financial penalties (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will examine case studies of medical biotechnology research and development, and will consider the industry context in which biotechnology is commercialised including: industry structure and competition; methods of financing, management approaches; the regulatory environment; product development and its commercial protection via intellectual property; and taking the product to market.</p>
<p>Students will examine case studies to analyse and evaluate the chances of commercialisation success of Australian companies in various phases of development, and present and justify their opinions in the form of class discussions, oral presentations and written business reports.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to;</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Interpret and critically evaluate the pathways from discovery science that lead to innovation and commercialisation of biotechnology innovations;</li>
<li>Analyse and evaluate the critical role of intellectual property in the commercialisation of biotechnology;</li>
<li>Apply advanced knowledge of how the major regulatory bodies [e.g. TGA (Therapeutic Goods Administration); FDA (Food &amp; Drug Administration); CTN (Clinical Trial Notification Scheme)] deal with specific innovations in the biotech / medtech sectors;</li>
<li>Evaluate and critically assess and predict the potential for commercial development and success of a specific biotechnology innovation;</li>
<li>Systematically build and validate arguments and opinions by sourcing and critically deconstructing relevant material and information, working both independently and as part of a team;</li>
<li>Effectively communicate complex concepts on scientific content and business processes in written or oral formats.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>2 x Case study reports (4,500 words total) (55%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>In-class worksheets (30%)</li>
<li>Group oral presentation (15 minutes) (10%)</li>
<li>Participation in workshop / class discussions (5%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>On-campus: 4-5 hours of contact per week, which will include a mix of presentations from industry experts and workshop activities.</p>
<p>Off campus: a minimum of 7-8 hours of private study, including preparation of work for discussion and assessment.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/biotechnology">Biotechnology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/biomedical-science">Biomedical science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">EAE4064</span> - Contemporary environmental earth science problems<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-EAE4064">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate, Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-earth-atmosphere-and-environment.html">School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<!-- TBA -->To be advised
        
        
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
    
      
        
        Dr Vanessa Wong and Professor Ian Cartwright
        
        
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=EAE4064&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-EAE4064">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Enrolment in the Master of Science</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/EAE5064.html">EAE5064</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will enable students to develop the skills required to conceive and deliver an applied research project in environmental earth science. Students will develop and carry out a research project in collaboration with other students on a key topic that is of relevance to industry, government or non-government organisations. The topic will be chosen by the students from a list provided by the unit coordinator. This unit will allow students to develop their research skills in earth sciences while working in team in developing a research project, formulating hypotheses and aims, collecting and analysing data, and interpreting and describing the implications of the results.  The presentation of the final results will develop presentation and written skills.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Develop a project proposal with appropriate research questions, aims, hypotheses and methodological approaches</li>
<li>Critically review the literature relevant to the project.</li>
<li>Generate, analyse and interpret data using appropriate data analysis methods</li>
<li>Communicate the findings, implications and limitations of the project in the broader scientific and social context in a clear and professional manner, in written and oral forms.</li>
<li>Collaborate effectively with their peers.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Project proposal: 20%</p>
<p>Poster presentation: 20%</p>
<p>Final report: 60%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>A total of 144 hrs for the semester consisting of a combination of structured workshops, group meetings, presentations, and individual study.</p>
<p>Short (one-day) site visits or field trips may also be required.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Master of Science in Earth Sciences</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">IAR4120</span> - Interior architecture design research project<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">18 points, SCA Band 2, 0.375 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-IAR4120">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nicole Kalms">Associate Professor Nicole Kalms</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nicole Kalms">Associate Professor Nicole Kalms</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=IAR4120&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-IAR4120">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/IAR4119.html">IAR4119</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/IAR4500.html">IAR4500</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/IAR4501.html">IAR4501</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/IAR4118.html">IAR4118</a></span>, IAR4108</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Interior Architecture Studio 8 is the culmination of the interior architecture studio stream. Students refine and apply the broad range of skills developed in preceding studios and associated units through the investigation of an independent design research project. The project is developed to express individual concerns and a platform for future professional endeavours.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate a high level of proficiency and autonomy in interior architectural production;</li>
<li>Identify and evaluate relevant research concepts, strategies and methods, and apply them in interior architecture and associated fields;</li>
<li>Develop design briefs and strategies in relation to research agendas;</li>
<li>Critically assess and apply contemporary design theories and practices within local and international contexts;</li>
<li>Engage productively with reflective practices in design and integrate relevant skills developed throughout the course;</li>
<li>Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>36 hours per week including 6 contact hours plus 30 hours of independent study, or equivalent.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">APG5704</span> - Discourse analysis<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-APG5704">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-linguistics.html">Linguistics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Louisa Willoughby">Dr Louisa Willoughby</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Louisa Willoughby">Dr Louisa Willoughby</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=APG5704&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-APG5704">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>First semester 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Every day, we engage with a wide range of different text types and speaking situations, from casual conversations with friends to news reports, medical appointments to advertising. In this unit, we look in detail at the typical features of these and other text types and explore the ways in which language can be used to manipulate, persuade or empower the hearer/ reader. The unit introduces students to a variety of approaches to doing discourse analysis, including Conversation Analysis, Critical Discourse Analysis and Corpus Linguistics. Students apply these methods to a range of texts and reflect on the appropriateness of each for answering different types of research questions.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit,  students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify and apply key terms and concepts used in discourse analysis;</li>
<li>explain the linguistic features that define different types of texts;</li>
<li>discuss strategies speakers/ writers use to build coherence and cohesion in both spoken and written text;</li>
<li>evaluate the appropriateness of different discourse analysis methods and techniques for answering specific research questions;</li>
<li>analyse how the language used in a text serves to persuade the reader and reflects a particular ideology;</li>
<li>apply insights from this unit to their own professional context.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/applied-linguistics">Applied linguistics</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">ACF5001</span> - Research project in accounting<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 3, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ACF5001">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-accounting.html">Department of Accounting</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Dean Hanlon">Dr Dean Hanlon</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ACF5001&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ACF5001">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACX4000.html">ACX4000</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Students must be enrolled in course B6002.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Students conduct and report on a research project that addresses an important issue in business. The research is likely to have practical as well as theoretical outcomes and implications. The research project is completed under the supervision of academic staff from the Department of Accounting.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>develop the ability to conduct and manage a planned study within a set time frame</li>
<li>demonstrate the ability to ask and answer critical questions that have accounting and policy significance at a professional standard</li>
<li>critically analyse the literature relevant to the field of study</li>
<li>devise and undertake empirical analysis using a range of techniques appropriate to the area of study</li>
<li>communicate research findings in a formal report following the relevant stylistic conventions.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average six/eight hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">MTE5882</span> - Advanced polymeric materials<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MTE5882">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-materials-science-and-engineering.html">Department of Materials Science and Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Neil Cameron">Professor Neil Cameron</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris McNeill">Professor Chris McNeill</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MTE5882&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MTE5882">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>None</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>None</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>None</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Polymers are a ubiquitous part of our everyday life. Advances in polymer synthesis, processing and engineering have led to new applications exploiting the unique properties of polymers to realise advanced technologies far removed from their initial application.</p>
<p>Building on a review of the fundamentals of polymer science, this unit will explore the use of polymers in a range of novel applications from biomedical applications to optoelectronic devices. Different classes of polymers will be discussed including conjugated polymers, block co-polymers and biopolymers with a view to linking the physical properties of the polymer chain to the functionality of the technological application.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>illustrate how the properties of polymer-based materials are derived from the macro-molecular nature of polymer chains</li>
<li>assess new polymer-based technologies and critique the advantages and disadvantages relevant to other non-polymer based technologies</li>
<li>design experiments to evaluate the performance of polymer based devices</li>
<li>evaluate the current state-of-the-art of emerging polymer technologies</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 50%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 hours of lectures/tutorials, 2 three hours laboratory sessions and 9 hours of private study per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Materials science</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3951</span> - Japanese popular culture and identity<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3951">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-japanese-studies.html">Japanese Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jason Jones">Dr Jason Jones</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jason Jones">Dr Jason Jones</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS3951&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3951">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>The successful completion of any 2nd year elective for the Japanese studies major OR any 2nd year elective for International studies(Asian studies stream) major OR permission of the unit coordinator.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This capstone unit consolidates general knowledge about Japan and its popular culture by approaching popular cultures as a means by which personal and national identities are constructed.  Popular culture, in this instance, is considered as a directive as well as a reflection of collective ideology. The genre of manga and anime, television and film, music, fashion and food cultures provide the contexts for students deepening their understanding of Japan's postwar cultural history; the role of new media and technology in society; personal identity as expressed through consumption and lifestyle; and important cultural expressions of socio-political resistance to hegemony.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Japanese literacy and communicative competence: Building on the competence in Japanese acquired through earlier studies, students will be able to identify and comprehend genre-specific features of Japanese evident in the popular culture genres studied and demonstrate an understanding of the ways in which they reflect and construct the social meanings embedded in the texts.</li>
<li>English literacy and communication skills: students will express ideas about Japanese culture and society verbally and in writing in sophisticated and nuanced ways through tutorial discussions and essay writing.</li>
<li>Knowledge about Japanese language, society and culture: through the study and critique of Japanese popular cultural representations, students will problematicise social concepts already learned and develop their own critical frameworks for understanding these genres.</li>
<li>Cross-cultural and inter-cultural competence: through the study of Japanese popular culture, students will have the opportunity to reflect on meanings associated with their own popular culture and national identity.</li>
<li>World view and ethical values: Through exploring social issues
(gender roles, personal identity, national identity, age hierarchy) in lectures, tutorials and written assignments students will reflect on their social values, respect for diversity and the ethical conduct and communication of research.</li>
<li>Research skills: Students will develop and demonstrate independent research skills and critical thinking through their research projects, and further develop a personal voice in their understanding of the research literature.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/global-asia">Global asia</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/japanese-studies">Japanese studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUR5923</span> - Intensive care nursing 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUR5923">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-nursing-and-midwifery.html">School of Nursing and Midwifery</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Rose Jaspers">Ms Rose Jaspers</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Rose Jaspers">Ms Rose Jaspers</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUR5923&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUR5923">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (Flexible)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in a Postgraduate degree</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The role of the intensive care nurse is diverse and challenging.  Specialist knowledge and skills are required to care for patients with actual or potential life-threatening injuries, illness or complications.</p>
<p>This unit focuses on the development of core skills including: oxygen therapy, non-invasive ventilation, Intubation/extubation, mechanical ventilation, Tracheostomy care, haemodynamic, monitoring, management of shocked states and Advanced Life Support.  Students will develop an understanding of the pathophysiology of disease states including cellular, respiratory, cardiac, and shock.</p>
<p>The student will develop advanced assessment skills underpinned by their knowledge of pathophysiology.  The combination of knowledge and skill sets learned by the student will enable them to appropriately assess and manage disease processes and measure efficacy of interventions such as those stated above as well as pharmacological interventions.  Assessment skills learned will enable the student to respond to an emergency and develop advanced life support skills.</p>
<p>This unit will encompass the development of skills that will enable the student to provide support for patients and significant others in ntensive care and will explore the intensive care nurses role in the multidisciplinary intensive care team.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Perform and reflect on clinical practice in accordance with the Australian College of Critical Care Nurses' framework</li>
<li>Apply advanced clinical reasoning related to the pathophysiology of neurological, respiratory, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, endocrine and renal systems in intensive care nursing</li>
<li>Demonstrate structured holistic assessment of an intensive care patient involving neurological, respiratory, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, endocrine and renal systems</li>
<li>Plan evidenced based care for an ICU patient applying clinical reasoning related to the pathophysiology of their illness.</li>
<li>Critique evidence related to assessment and therapeutic interventions used in the planning of care.</li>
<li>Assess basic haemodynamic monitoring and analyse and interpret 12 lead ECGs, blood gas data and advanced respiratory findings, critically evaluating management of patient instability.</li>
<li>Provide and evaluate care for patients requiring high flow oxygen therapy, non-invasive ventilation.</li>
<li>Provide and evaluate care for patients requiring intubation, mechanical ventilation, respiratory weaning, tracheostomy and extubation</li>
<li>Attain competency in advanced life support including safely transporting ICU patients to other clinical areas</li>
<li>Define and state classifications of shock describing pathophysiology and causes, clinical features, treatment and stages of shock.</li>
<li>Critically evaluate pharmacological and other therapeutic interventions used to manage neurological, respiratory, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, endocrine and renal system conditions in specialist nursing practice</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Students must be working as a Registered Nurse in an Intensive Care Unit for a minimum of 3 days/week</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>End of semester written exam (3 hours) (40% )(hurdle)</li>
<li>ISAP Case (2,250 words) (30%)</li>
<li>4 x online Respondus lock down browser mediated quizzes (30%)</li>
<li>Clinical Assessment and Performance Appraisal Hurdle (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>6 hours of contact hours and 6 hours of self- directed study per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing">Nursing</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/intensive-care-nursing">Intensive care nursing</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">IAR4119</span> - Interior architecture studio 7<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 2, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-IAR4119">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Matthew Bird">Dr Matthew Bird</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Matthew Bird">Dr Matthew Bird</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=IAR4119&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-IAR4119">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/IAR3118.html">IAR3118</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/IAR4117.html">IAR4117</a></span>, IAR4107</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Within this unit students engage in a range of studio design projects which have quota restrictions. For distribution into studio project groups, consideration will be given to student preference forms, academic performance, and previous design studio experiences. Weighted Average Mark (WAM) may be taken into account to ensure there is an even distribution of students in the studio project groups. Studio project group allocation will be decided by the Program Coordinator and Chief Examiner of the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit builds on skills developed in previous studios and applies these to a range of focused projects that extend and explore transformational practices in interior architecture. In this studio successful project outcomes will be of an advanced level of complexity. They will provide an opportunity to integrate learning across the course with the development of responsive design practices. A number of focused studio projects will be offered.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Respond creatively to design briefs of advanced complexity;</li>
<li>Investigate relevant concepts and precedents in design discourse and incorporate these into design proposals;</li>
<li>Demonstrate the resolution of competing needs during the development of a design proposal;</li>
<li>Apply design strategies with increasing awareness and independence;</li>
<li>Explore and communicate design schemes through appropriate modes of representation;</li>
<li>Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>24 hours per week including 6 contact hours plus 18 hours of independent study, or equivalent.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2795</span> - Yiddish language, culture and literature 2A<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2795">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-australian-centre-for-jewish-civilisation.html">Australian Centre for Jewish Civilisation</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ena Burstin">Ms Ena Burstin</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ena Burstin">Ms Ena Burstin</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2795">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS1337.html">ATS1337</a></span> - Yiddish 1B or an approved equivalent standard</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Yiddish 2A is a continuation of first year level Yiddish. The central feature of both Yiddish 2A and 2B will be the more advanced teaching of Yiddish as a living language, as a tool for both written and spoken communication. The course is designed for students who wish to improve their knowledge of the subject both in its literary and conversational form. The course will include use of non-literary texts and exercises to develop grammatical, syntactic and idiomatic mastery of the language. An additional component will utilise Yiddish literary texts of Australia as well as of other countries. Completion of parts A and B will prepare students to continue to an eventual major in the subject.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of Yiddish 2 students will:</p>
<ul>
<li>be able to demonstrate a fluency in reading and writing Yiddish script</li>
<li>have a working understanding of spoken Standard Modern Yiddish</li>
<li>acquire the ability to write original short essays in Yiddish; acquire advanced skills required for Yiddish conversation</li>
<li>have an appreciation of the richness of Yiddish as a rich literary and cultural tradition</li>
<li>begin to demonstrate a critical appraisal of selected Yiddish authors and poets and their writings</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Exam: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/jewish-studies">Jewish studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">FNA2112</span> - Contemporary practices 4<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FNA2112">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-fine-art.html">Department of Fine Art</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nicholas Mangan">Dr Nicholas Mangan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nicholas Mangan">Dr Nicholas Mangan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FNA2112&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FNA2112&amp;tpCode=T3-58&amp;tpYear=2019">Trimester 3</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FNA2112">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-prato.html">Prato</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Trimester 3 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FNA2111.html">FNA2111</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>Any FNA, VIS or VPR level 2 unit</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is the fourth in the sequence for students to continue a range of leading contemporary art practices and methodologies. The unit promotes conceptual and material processes through interdisciplinary exchange, material and fabrication procedures. Associated projects are introduced based on theories of contemporary art practices, collaborative practices and individual modes of research focused outcomes. Students will develop inventive and sustainable solutions to a series of projects that will enable them to continue to develop a personal methodology and language.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Have further extended both skills in art making and student vocabulary of materials and studio processes;</li>
<li>Possess considerable manipulative skills in students chosen area of self-expression;</li>
<li>Have further developed levels of experimentation and investigation within students work, moving towards a focus on specific themes and technologies;</li>
<li>Be familiar with current issues in fine art and recognise the potential to produce works within the framework of contemporary culture;</li>
<li>Have developed an increased capacity for the constructive appraisal of their own work, and that of others, and are able to articulate this through oral presentations and written documentation, and;</li>
<li>Have an increased understanding and practice the rules of occupational health and safety in force in the studio, and are able to collaborate and co-operate  safely and productively within the studio environment.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>24 hours per week including 8 contact hours plus 16 hours of independent study and studio practice.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">RTS2001</span> - Professional practice in radiation therapy<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-RTS2001">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-medical-imaging-and-radiation-sciences.html">Department of Medical Imaging and Radiation Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Paul Lombardo">Mr Paul Lombardo</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Caroline Wright">A. Prof Caroline Wright</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Quota applies</p>
<p>This unit is quota restricted. Selection is on a first-in, first enrolled basis
      
      
      </p><p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=RTS2001&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-RTS2001">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>M20024</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RTS4102.html">RTS4102</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is designed to provide students with the opportunity to explore the role of the radiation therapist and the role of the multidisciplinary team in radiation therapy.</p>
<p>Students will investigate what constitutes appropriate professional behaviour in the health care setting and they will become familiar with use of appropriate medical terminology.</p>
<p>Students will also investigate and demonstrate occupational health and safety, radiation safety, infection control and manual handling principles.</p>
<p>The unit will support students to develop an awareness of cultural and communication competence, and allow students to begin to understand and articulate some of the challenges faced by the diverse range of patients being treated in radiation therapy centres.</p>
<p>Cancer management strategies will be introduced to students and the concept of reflective practice will be introduced with a variety of models of reflection.</p>
<p>This unit introduces students to the clinical radiation therapy environment in the format of a short clinical orientation.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the specific needs of cancer patients and outline a range of cancer management strategies</li>
<li>Describe and apply the principles of radiation safety, quality management, occupational health and safety and organisational policy related to radiation therapy practice.</li>
<li>Describe the process of reflective practice and demonstrate critical reflection on experience</li>
<li>Explain and apply communication principles and techniques related to radiation therapy practice.</li>
<li>Determine the influence of socio-cultural factors on patient attitudes and responses to radiation therapy</li>
<li>Evaluate the principles of multidisciplinary team working and apply these to radiation therapy and wider health care practice</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Two days of clinical orientation in a radiation therapy centre allocated by the Department of Medical Imaging and Radiation Sciences.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>iSAP clinical action plan (2000 words) and iSAP comparative report (500 words) (35%)</li>
<li>3 x 30 minute online moodle quizzes (10%)</li>
<li>2x 500 word reflective portfolio pivotal incident reports (10%)</li>
<li>2 hour end of semester written exam (45%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle requirement:</p>
<ul>
<li>80% attendance at tutorials</li>
<li>100% attendance at clinical orientation days</li>
<li>Students must pass each element of assessment to pass the unit</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Three hours per week contact hours, plus nine hours per week private study. Students will attend a one hour lecture and a two hour tutorial weekly.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/radiography-and-medical-imaging">Radiography and medical imaging</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/radiation-sciences">Radiation sciences</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">
<!-- breadcrumbs -->
<nav class="breadcrumbs mobile-hidden" id="breadcrumbs">
<p class="visuallyhidden" id="breadcrumb__label">You are here:</p>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">BMH4120</span> - Biomedicine research project part-time B<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">18 points, SCA Band 2, 0.375 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BMH4120">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<!-- TBA -->To be advised
        
        
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<!-- TBA -->To be advised
        
        
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMH4120&amp;tpCode=FY-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Full year</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMH4120&amp;tpCode=S2-S1-02&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester to First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BMH4120">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Full year 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 to First semester 2020 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Enrolment in an approved Honours in the discipline of Anatomy and developmental biology, Biochemistry, Human pathology, Immunology, Microbiology, Pharmacology or Physiology</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMH4220.html">BMH4220</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>BCH4120, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMS4100.html">BMS4100</a></span>, DEV4120, IMB4120, MIC4120, PHA4120, PHY4120</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Students will undertake a supervised research project of a publishable standard. Candidates may commence the Honours year at the beginning of either the first or second semester. Students will research literature relevant to their topic, carry out a research project and present the results of their study in both written and oral form. Information about the research projects is available from the course coordinator and at information sessions held during the second semester of third year.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Critically review the scientific literature that underpins the area of the research project;</li>
<li>Undertake a supervised research project and contribute to project design and management;</li>
<li>Apply appropriate laboratory techniques, research methodologies and data analysis methods to collect, interpret and report research findings;</li>
<li>Effectively present research and findings orally showing a firm grasp of the area;</li>
<li>Analyse research undertaken in the context of the discipline area and report findings in an extended written report.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Assessment will be the submission of a research thesis and thesis review and the presentation of a seminar(s) about the research project and findings.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>To be advised by Honours coordinator</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Anatomy and developmental biology</p>
<p><a href="../aos/biochemistry">Biochemistry</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/human-pathology">Human pathology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/immunology">Immunology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/microbiology">Microbiology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/pharmacology">Pharmacology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/physiology">Physiology</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">RAD5504</span> - Magnetic resonance imaging: Musculoskeletal system<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-RAD5504">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-medical-imaging-and-radiation-sciences.html">Department of Medical Imaging and Radiation Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mark Strudwick">Dr Mark Strudwick</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mark Strudwick">Dr Mark Strudwick</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=RAD5504&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=RAD5504&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-RAD5504">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (Online)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RAD4503.html">RAD4503</a></span> (for M6001)</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RAD4503.html">RAD4503</a></span> (for Grad Cert MRI)</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit extends knowledge of the basic physical principles of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and addresses safety and the protocols and processing methods used to image the upper and lower extremity.</p>
<p>The unit will introduce the student to the concept of evidence - based health care practice and how the principles apply to MRI practice.</p>
<p>The unit will examine the role played by the practitioner in the application of safety principles within the MRI suite. Clinical indications and the preparation of the patient including the correct positioning methods for the upper and lower extremity will be addressed.</p>
<p>The purpose of the common sequences used to image specific structures will be covered and students will learn how to select the most appropriate imaging protocol for the common sequences from within an evidence - based framework.</p>
<p>The unit will enable students to recognise the characteristics of the MRI representation of the common pathologies affecting the extremities.</p>
<p>The unit will conclude with an examination of the application of quality assurance and quality control principles to MRI imaging of the musculo-skeletal system.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to;</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Apply principles of evidence-based health care practice to MRI imaging in the clinical context</li>
<li>Explain the role played by the practitioner in the application of safety principles within the MRI suite</li>
<li>Describe a range of clinical indications, patient presentations, patient preparation and positioning methods for MRI studies of the extremities</li>
<li>Select the appropriate MRI protocol and post processing techniques for MRI studies of the extremities from within an evidence-based framework</li>
<li>Recognise the characteristics of the MRI representation of common pathologies affecting the upper and lower extremity</li>
<li>Apply the principles of quality assurance and quality control to MRI imaging in the clinical context</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Secure online examination (45 minutes) (15%)</li>
<li>6 x Advanced MRI clinical case studies (500 words each) (70%)</li>
<li>Technical quality assurance and quality control report (1,500 words) (15%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>On-line delivery - course designed only for post graduate students.</p>
<p>There will be video clips and video-conferences available throughout the course to assist in directing students. Discussion forums will be initiated to further direct student outcomes.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Radiography and medical imaging</p>
<p>Radiation sciences</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">DPH6005</span> - Doctor of public health: Public health practice<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 2, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-DPH6005">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-epidemiology-and-preventive-medicine.html">Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robert Hall">Dr Robert Hall</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robert Hall">Dr Robert Hall</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-DPH6005">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>DPH6001 and DPH6002</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Supervised practical placement in University Departments and Centres, hospitals, affiliated research Institutes, community health services, non-government organisations or the Dept of Human Services. Giving students the opportunity to interact with practising public health professionals. Students are co-supervised by a member of the Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences academic staff.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>demonstrate a thorough understanding of quantative research methods in public health;</li>
<li>design, develop and present an original research protocol;</li>
<li>prepare an application for approval by an Ethics Committee;</li>
<li>design and outline methods for validating a questionnaire suitable for data entry; and</li>
<li>write a paper suitable for publication in a peer reviewed journal.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Written report 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Public health and preventive medicine PhD program</p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2283</span> - The archaeology of empires<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2283">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-centre-for-ancient-cultures.html">Centre for Ancient Cultures</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Hilary Gopnik">Dr Hilary Gopnik</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Hilary Gopnik">Dr Hilary Gopnik</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2283&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2283">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of first-year Arts units.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Towards the beginning of the first millennium BCE the Assyrian state in upper Mesopotamia started to expand its borders. Many territorial states had done this before, but the military and economic ideology of conquest that motivated this expansion created a new kind of political entity -the empire- which was to set the stage for the political strategy of the next one thousand years. When the Assyrian empire finally collapsed, its territory was quickly taken by the Babylonians and Medes, who in turn were conquered by the Persian Empire, which, after 200 years of dominion over a territory stretching from the Mediterranean to the mountains of Afghanistan, itself fell to the army of Alexander the Great and his generals. In this unit we will examine how the material culture recovered by archaeology - from the palaces, battle accounts, and art of the elite to the houses, pottery, and ritual figurines of those they conquered - can tell us how these early empires extended their power to neighbouring communities and how these communities adapted to, and sometimes resisted, the encroaching empires that surrounded them. Cultures covered include Egypt, Ancient Judah-Israel, Assyria, Urartu, Babylon, Media, Persia and the Hellenistic empires.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>know the cultures and historical periods of the Ancient Near East in the first millennium BCE;</li>
<li>understand how to use archaeological evidence to study ancient empires;</li>
<li>identify imperial tactics of control and the conquered regions' tactics of resistance;</li>
<li>distinguish the effects of imperial expansion on past societies;</li>
<li>critically appraise arguments about ancient empires through the use of archaeological and historical evidence.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Exam: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/archaeology-and-ancient-history">Archaeology and ancient history</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>
